subject: Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: Agreed! Thanks! ... work-around ... want ... your ... sounding ... quite ... the ... phonemic ... owe. ... with ... the ... as you ... no ... raced ... con-
messageBody:
Agreed! Thanks!

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...>
wrote:
>
>
>
> I would recommend against using an "o" even for a private
"work-around"
> when that is not the sound needed for the word. In my opinion, you
want
> to indelibly link the QS letters with the sounds they represent in
your
> mind to foster automatic reading, i.e. without the necessity of
sounding
> out words. After all, this is what we do with T.O.
>
> I think the use of a letter that represents a different sound in place
> of the correct letter, would be counter productive and harmful to your
> comprehension. I would just advise you to realize that QS does not
> require that every letter be joined to every other letter. QS is
quite
> cursive as Read designed it. The small amount of time required for
the
> occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion of muddying the
phonemic
> character, might I say, "purity," of the alphabet.
>
> Just my two cents.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
> On 8/18/2011 12:12 PM, cossyrosario wrote:
> >
> > Thanks, Sid.
> >
> > The reason why I didn't use this work-around is because I've been
> > trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent
> > /sounds/ of the English language.
> >
> > In com- con- the o sound is like the u in utter (as in commend,
> > contend), or like the o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when
> > written as in Latin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in
owe.
> > Therefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con-
with
> > the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.
> >
> > However, if I were making notes for myself, as is the case most of
the
> > time I use QuikScript, I could certainly use the o as a private
> > work-around.
> >
> > What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for temporary
> > private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion to be
> > transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a prefix,
> > thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.
> >
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sid Tanaban sidban2@ wrote:
> > >
> > > com or con can be written in one stroke. Â Just write the "o"
as you
> > would in latin letters and add the "m" Â Unfortunately, I have
no
> > idea how to do this on a computer.
> > > Sid
> > >
> > > --- On Wed, 8/17/11, cossyrosario cossyrosario@ wrote:
> > >
> > > From: cossyrosario cossyrosario@
> > > Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the
> > prefixes com- and con- as contractions
> > > To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > > Date: Wednesday, August 17, 2011, 11:20 PM
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Thank you, Steve!
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > In my hurry to learn as much as possible as soon as possible, I
raced
> > >
> > > through the manual, and must have raced past the section on com-
con- as
> > >
> > > it must have seemed obvious, with nothing new to learn! Or so it
must
> > >
> > > have seemed at the time.
> > >

> >
